The Continent's Fossilized Forest.
Believe it or not,
the Antarctic was actually once covered with towering forests.
A hundred million years ago,
the Earth was in a massive grip of a greenhouse effect.
Rainforests in the south, inhabited by different dinosaurs,
existed in their place, and polar ice caps had already melted.
Among the first people to uncover pieces of evidence of a once green Antarctic,
was the explorer, Robert Falcon Scott.
He stumbled over a variety of fossil plants at 82Â° degrees south

His discoveries of those fossils opened up an entirely new window
on the subtropical past of the continent.
When you visit Antarctica's cold frozen wasteland,

where kilometers of thick ice blocks now exist,
but many archaeological records provide undeniable evidence
that climate fluctuations have happened throughout the history of the planet.
Admiral Byrd's Hollow Earth Theory.
One of the biggest discoveries linked with Antarctica's mysteries
is the Hollow Earth theory by Admiral Byrd.
Rear Admiral Richard Byrd is an iconic figure in American history,
known for his explorations of the polar extremities of the planet
particularly of the North Pole.
He's widely known as a pioneer and a hero,
a decorated naval officer and explorer.
There are many theories linked to his name,
and one that is less widely known is the Hollow Earth theory,
which suggests that Earth is hollow,
